objects.name: SVR
objects.description: Russian Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR) cyber actors [...] are exploiting CVE-2023-42793 at a large scale, targeting servers hosting JetBrains TeamCity software since September 2023.

objects.name: JetBrains TeamCity
objects.description: Software developers use TeamCity software to manage and automate software compilation, building, testing, and releasing.

objects.name: CVE-2023-42793
objects.description: By choosing to exploit CVE-2023-42793, a software development program, the authoring agencies assess the SVR could benefit from access to victims, particularly by allowing the threat actors to compromise the networks of dozens of software developers.

objects.name: TeamCity Campaign
objects.description: Russian Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR) cyber actors [...] are exploiting CVE-2023-42793 at a large scale, targeting servers hosting JetBrains TeamCity software since September 2023.

objects.name: Any exploitable organization
objects.description: Generally, the victim types do not fit into any sort of pattern or trend, aside from having an unpatched, Internet-reachable JetBrains TeamCity server, leading to the assessment that SVR’s exploitation of these victims’ networks was opportunistic in nature and not necessarily a targeted attack.

objects.name: SolarWinds Orion
objects.description: Although the SVR used such access to compromise SolarWinds and its customers in 2020, [...]

objects.name: Spearphishing Campaign
objects.description: A decade ago, public reports about SVR cyber activity focused largely on the SVR’s spearphishing operations, targeting government agencies, think tanks and policy analysis organizations, educational institutions, and political organizations.

objects.name: Government agencies, think tanks, policy analysis organizations, educational institutions, political organizations
objects.description: The SVR’s spearphishing operations have targeted government agencies, think tanks and policy analysis organizations, educational institutions, and political organizations.

objects.name: Spearphishing - MITRE T1566
objects.description: The SVR’s spearphishing operations have targeted government agencies, think tanks and policy analysis organizations, educational institutions, and political organizations.

objects.name: Diplomatic Orbiter Campaign
objects.description: The SVR’s use of spear phishing operations are visible today in its ongoing Diplomatic Orbiter campaign, primarily targeting diplomatic agencies.

objects.name: Diplomatic agencies
objects.description: The SVR’s use of spear phishing operations are visible today in its ongoing Diplomatic Orbiter campaign, primarily targeting diplomatic agencies.

objects.name: WellMess Campaign
objects.description: n July 2020, U.S., U.K., and Canadian Governments jointly published an advisory revealing the SVR’s exploitation of CVEs to gain initial access to networks, and its deployment of custom malware known as WellMess, WellMail, and Sorefang to target organizations involved in COVID-19 vaccine development.

objects.name: WellMess
objects.description: In July 2020, U.S., U.K., and Canadian Governments jointly published an advisory revealing the SVR’s exploitation of CVEs to gain initial access to networks, and its deployment of custom malware known as WellMess, WellMail, and Sorefang to target organizations involved in COVID-19 vaccine development.

objects.name: WellMail
objects.description: In July 2020, U.S., U.K., and Canadian Governments jointly published an advisory revealing the SVR’s exploitation of CVEs to gain initial access to networks, and its deployment of custom malware known as WellMess, WellMail, and Sorefang to target organizations involved in COVID-19 vaccine development.

objects.name: Sorefang
objects.description: In July 2020, U.S., U.K., and Canadian Governments jointly published an advisory revealing the SVR’s exploitation of CVEs to gain initial access to networks, and its deployment of custom malware known as WellMess, WellMail, and Sorefang to target organizations involved in COVID-19 vaccine development.

objects.name: Organizations involved in COVID-19 vaccine development
objects.description: In July 2020, U.S., U.K., and Canadian Governments jointly published an advisory revealing the SVR’s exploitation of CVEs to gain initial access to networks, and its deployment of custom malware known as WellMess, WellMail, and Sorefang to target organizations involved in COVID-19 vaccine development.

objects.name: Energy companies
objects.description: Although not listed in the 2020 advisory, the authoring agencies can now disclose that the SVR’s WellMess campaign also targeted energy companies.

objects.name: Network Service Discovery - MITRE T1046
objects.description: The SVR performed network reconnaissance using a mix of built-in commands and additional tools, such as port scanner and PowerSploit, which it launched into memory [T1046].

objects.name: PowerSploit
objects.description: The SVR performed network reconnaissance using a mix of built-in commands and additional tools, such as port scanner and PowerSploit, which it launched into memory [T1046].

objects.name: System Owner/User Discovery - MITRE T1033
objects.description: Initial observations show the SVR used the following basic, built-in commands to perform host reconnaissance [T1033],[T1059.003],[T1592.002]: [...]

objects.name: Command and Scripting Interpreter - MITRE T1059
objects.description: Initial observations show the SVR used the following basic, built-in commands to perform host reconnaissance [T1033],[T1059.003],[T1592.002]: [...]

objects.name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel - MITRE T1041
objects.description: Additionally, the authoring agencies have observed the SVR exfiltrating files [T1041] which may provide insight into the host system’s operating system

objects.name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation - MITRE T1068
objects.description: SVR cyber actors exploit JetBrains TeamCity vulnerability to achieve escalated privileges. To avoid detection, the SVR cyber actors used a “Bring Your Own Vulnerable Driver” technique to disable EDR and AV defense mechanisms.

objects.name: Impair Defenses - MITRE T1562
objects.description: To avoid detection, the SVR used a “Bring Your Own Vulnerable Driver” [T1068] technique to disable or outright kill endpoint detection and response (EDR) and antivirus (AV) software [T1562.001]

objects.name: Boot or Logon Autostart Execution - MITRE T1547
objects.description: SVR cyber actors used C:\Windows\system32\ntoskrnl.exe to configure automatic system boot settings to maintain persistence

objects.name: Steal or Forge Kerberos Tickets - MITRE T1558
objects.description: To secure long-term access to the environment, the SVR used the Rubeus toolkit to craft Ticket Granting Tickets (TGTs) [T1558.001]

objects.name: Rubeus
objects.description: To secure long-term access to the environment, the SVR used the Rubeus toolkit to craft Ticket Granting Tickets (TGTs) [T1558.001]

objects.name: OneDrive
objects.description: To avoid detection by network monitoring, the SVR devised a covert C2 channel that used Microsoft OneDrive and Dropbox cloud services. [...] OneDrive is used as a primary communication channel while Dropbox is treated as a backup channel [T1567].

objects.name: Dropbox
objects.description: To avoid detection by network monitoring, the SVR devised a covert C2 channel that used Microsoft OneDrive and Dropbox cloud services. [...] OneDrive is used as a primary communication channel while Dropbox is treated as a backup channel [T1567].

objects.name: Graphical Proton
objects.description: GraphicalProton is a simplistic backdoor that uses OneDrive, Dropbox, and randomly generated BMPs [T1027.001] to exchange data with the SVR operator

objects.name: GraphicalProton HTTPS variant
objects.description: a variant of GraphicalProton backdoor recently introduced by the SVR that forgoes using cloud-based services as a C2 channel and instead relies on HTTP request.

objects.name: WordPress
objects.description: To legitimize the C2 channel, SVR used a re-registered expired domain set up with dummy WordPress website.

objects.name: SharpChromium
objects.description: In a few specific cases, the SVR used the SharpChromium tool to obtain sensitive browser data such as session cookies, browsing history, or saved logins

objects.name: DSinternals
objects.description: SVR also used DSInternals open source tool to interact with Directory Services. DSInternals allows to obtain a sensitive Domain information.

objects.name: Rsockstun
objects.description: In selected environments the SVR used an additional tool named, “rr.exe”—a modified open source reverse socks tunneler named Rsockstun—to establish a tunnel to the C2 infrastructure [T1572]

objects.name: rr.exe
objects.description: In selected environments the SVR used an additional tool named, “rr.exe”—a modified open source reverse socks tunneler named Rsockstun—to establish a tunnel to the C2 infrastructure [T1572]

objects.name: C2 infrastructure
objects.description: The authoring agencies are aware of the following infrastructure used in conjunction with “rr.exe”: 65.20.97[.]203:443, Poetpages[.]com:8443

objects.name: EDRSandBlast
objects.description: This was done using an open source project called “EDRSandBlast.” The authoring agencies have observed the SVR using EDRSandBlast to remove protected process light (PPL) protection, which is used for controlling and protecting running processes and protecting them from infection.

objects.name: Mimikatz
objects.description: To facilitate privilege escalation [T1098], the SVR used multiple techniques, including WinPEAS, NoLMHash registry key modification, and the Mimikatz tool.

objects.name: VCPerf
objects.description: In several cases SVR attempted to hide their backdoors via: [...] backdooring an open source application developed by Microsoft named vcperf. SVR modified and copied publicly available source code. After execution, backdoored vcperf dropped several DLLs to disc, one of those being a GraphicalProton backdoor

objects.name: Modded VCPerf
objects.description: In several cases SVR attempted to hide their backdoors via: [...] backdooring an open source application developed by Microsoft named vcperf. SVR modified and copied publicly available source code. After execution, backdoored vcperf dropped several DLLs to disc, one of those being a GraphicalProton backdoor

objects.name: Zabbix vulnerability
objects.description: In several cases SVR attempted to hide their backdoors via: [...] Abusing a DLL hijacking vulnerability in Zabbix software by replacing a legitimate Zabbix DLL with their one containing GraphicalProton backdoor

objects.name: Webroot vulnerability
objects.description: In several cases SVR attempted to hide their backdoors via: [...] Abusing a DLL hijacking vulnerability in Webroot antivirus software by replacing a legitimate Webroot DLL with their one containing GraphicalProton backdoor

objects.name: Network Indicators of Compromise
objects.description: The authoring agencies have observed the SVR using the following network indicators of compromise (IOCs):

objects.name: rr.exe hash
objects.description: The authoring agencies have observed the SVR using the following hash indicators of compromise (IOCs):

objects.name: GraphicalProton hashes
objects.description: The authoring agencies have observed the SVR using the following hash indicators of compromise (IOCs):
objects.pattern: [file:hashes.'SHA-256' = '01B5F7094DE0B2C6F8E28AA9A2DED678C166D615530E595621E692A9C0240732' OR file:hashes.'SHA-256' = '34C8F155601A3948DDB0D60B582CFE87DE970D443CC0E05DF48B1A1AD2E42B5E' OR file:hashes.'SHA-256' = '620D2BF14FE345EEF618FDD1DAC242B3A0BB65CCB75699FE00F7C671F2C1D869' OR file:hashes.'SHA-256' = '773F0102720AF2957859D6930CD09693824D87DB705B3303CEF9EE794375CE13' OR file:hashes.'SHA-256' = '7B666B978DBBE7C032CEF19A90993E8E4922B743EE839632BFA6D99314EA6C53' OR file:hashes.'SHA-256' = '8AFB71B7CE511B0BCE642F46D6FC5DD79FAD86A58223061B684313966EFEF9C7' OR file:hashes.'SHA-256' = '971F0CED6C42DD2B6E3EA3E6C54D0081CF9B06E79A38C2EDE3A2C5228C27A6DC' OR file:hashes.'SHA-256' = 'CB83E5CB264161C28DE76A44D0EDB450745E773D24BEC5869D85F69633E44DCF' OR file:hashes.'SHA-256' = 'CD3584D61C2724F927553770924149BB51811742A461146B15B34A26C92CAD43' OR file:hashes.'SHA-256' = 'EBE231C90FAD02590FC56D5840ACC63B90312B0E2FEE7DA3C7606027ED92600E' OR file:hashes.'SHA-256' = 'F1B40E6E5A7CBC22F7A0BD34607B13E7E3493B8AAD7431C47F1366F0256E23EB' OR file:hashes.'SHA-256' = 'C7B01242D2E15C3DA0F45B8ADEC4E6913E534849CDE16A2A6C480045E03FBEE4' OR file:hashes.'SHA-256' = '4BF1915785D7C6E0987EB9C15857F7AC67DC365177A1707B14822131D43A6166']

objects.name: GraphicalProton HTTPS variant hashes
objects.description: The authoring agencies have observed the SVR using the following hash indicators of compromise (IOCs):
objects.pattern: [file:hashes.'SHA-256' = '18101518EAE3EEC6EBE453DE4C4C380160774D7C3ED5C79E1813013AC1BB0B93' OR file:hashes.'SHA-256' = '19F1EF66E449CF2A2B0283DBB756850CCA396114286E1485E35E6C672C9C3641' OR file:hashes.'SHA-256' = '1E74CF0223D57FD846E171F4A58790280D4593DF1F23132044076560A5455FF8' OR file:hashes.'SHA-256' = '219FB90D2E88A2197A9E08B0E7811E2E0BD23D59233287587CCC4642C2CF3D67' OR file:hashes.'SHA-256' = '92C7693E82A90D08249EDEAFBCA6533FED81B62E9E056DEC34C24756E0A130A6' OR file:hashes.'SHA-256' = 'B53E27C79EED8531B1E05827ACE2362603FB9F77F53CEE2E34940D570217CBF7' OR file:hashes.'SHA-256' = 'C37C109171F32456BBE57B8676CC533091E387E6BA733FBAA01175C43CFB6EBD' OR file:hashes.'SHA-256' = 'C40A8006A7B1F10B1B42FDD8D6D0F434BE503FB3400FB948AC9AB8DDFA5B78A0' OR file:hashes.'SHA-256' = 'C832462C15C8041191F190F7A88D25089D57F78E97161C3003D68D0CC2C4BAA3' OR file:hashes.'SHA-256' = 'F6194121E1540C3553273709127DFA1DAAB96B0ACFAB6E92548BFB4059913C69']

objects.name: Modded VCPerf hash
objects.description: The authoring agencies have observed the following hash indicators of compromise (IOCs):

objects.name: Log message indicator
objects.description: On a Windows system, the log file C:\TeamCity\logs\teamcity-server.log will contain a log message when an attacker modified the internal.properties file. There will also be a log message for every process created via the /app/rest/debug/processes endpoint.
objects.pattern: [file:name = 'internal.properties' AND file:parent_directory_ref.path = 'C:\\ProgramData\\JetBrains\\TeamCity\\config' AND file:x_custom_property = 'File edited by user with id=1']

objects.name: Sigma rule 1
objects.description: Detects whoami.exe execution and listing of privileges.

objects.name: Sigma rule 2
objects.description: Detects nltest.exe execution and DC listing.

objects.name: Sigma rule 3
objects.description: Detects DLL execution via WMI.

objects.name: Sigma rule 4
objects.description: Detects processes with 'connect' and 'pass' as arguments indicating potentially malicious activity.

objects.name: Sigma rule 10
objects.description: Detects PowerShell scripts enumerating services or drives, potential information gathering activity.

objects.name: Sigma rule 5
objects.description: Detects compression of files from temporary directories, possibly in preparation for data exfiltration.

objects.name: Sigma rule 6
objects.description: Detects loading of DLLs with specific names known to be associated with the GraphicalProton backdoor.

objects.name: Sigma rule 7
objects.description: Detects the use of 'reg.exe' to save sensitive registry entries, possibly for exfiltration or backup before making malicious modifications.

objects.name: Sigma rule 8
objects.description: Detects creation or manipulation of scheduled tasks with names associated with the GraphicalProton backdoor.
objects.pattern: EventID: ['4698', '4699', '4702'] AND TaskName|contains: ['\\Microsoft\\Windows\\IISUpdateService', '\\Microsoft\\Windows\\WindowsDefenderService', '\\Microsoft\\Windows\\WindowsDefenderService2', '\\Microsoft\\DefenderService', '\\Microsoft\\Windows\\DefenderUPDService', '\\Microsoft\\Windows\\WiMSDFS', '\\Microsoft\\Windows\\Application Experience\\StartupAppTaskCkeck', '\\Microsoft\\Windows\\Windows Error Reporting\\SubmitReporting', '\\Microsoft\\Windows\\Windows Defender\\Defender Update Service', '\\WindowUpdate', '\\Microsoft\\Windows\\Windows Error Reporting\\CheckReporting', '\\Microsoft\\Windows\\Application Experience\\StartupAppTaskCheck', '\\Microsoft\\Windows\\Speech\\SpeechModelInstallTask', '\\Microsoft\\Windows\\Windows Filtering Platform\\BfeOnServiceStart', '\\Microsoft\\Windows\\Data Integrity Scan\\Data Integrity Update', '\\Microsoft\\Windows\\WindowsUpdate\\Scheduled AutoCheck', '\\Microsoft\\Windows\\ATPUpd', '\\Microsoft\\Windows\\Windows Defender\\Service Update', '\\Microsoft\\Windows\\WindowsUpdate\\Scheduled Check', '\\Microsoft\\Windows\\WindowsUpdate\\Scheduled AutoCheck', '\\Defender', '\\defender']

objects.name: Sigma rule 9
objects.description: Detects modifications to specific sensitive registry keys, indicating potential security policy bypass attempts.

objects.name: Sigma rule 11
objects.description: Detects the loading of drivers by their names or hashes known to be malicious or used in unauthorized modifications.

objects.name: YARA rule
objects.description: The following rule detects most known GraphicalProton variants: [...]
